awd_titl_txt: ABI Innovation: Advanced informatics and effective algorithms to enable CryoEM protein structure prediction and density analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for an interdisciplinary project to develop efficient computational methods and tools for determination of protein structures from 3D images in the presence of errors. Understanding the machinery of large molecular assemblies has been significantly enhanced by the cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) technique. This technique allows the visualization of tens to over a thousand interacting molecules in an assembly and hence provides direct insights into important biological functions and mechanisms that cause abnormal function. The Electron Microscopy Data Bank (EMDB) archives density images of molecular assemblies at resolutions ranging from 2Å to 100Å and the rapidly accumulating data are valuable resources for data mining for enhanced accuracy in interpretation. The research will concretely demonstrate the applicability of data mining the EMDB and the use of sophisticated graph algorithmic methods for better protein structure prediction. The computational methods and tools being developed can be used to interpret large molecular assemblies that have important biological functions such as viruses, membrane-bound channels and cellular machines. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for designing drugs and vaccines. The data mining and algorithmic techniques developed are very likely to be applicable for solving other computational problems, especially those dealing with searching large spaces and where one has to deal with data errors. Through the involvement of undergraduate researchers and summer high school students in the project, particularly women and those to be recruited from the African-American community, the project will contribute to the NSF goal of strengthening the pipeline and broadening participation in STEM fields.

The long term goal of this project is to develop sequential and parallel computational methods and tools to derive atomic structures for EMDB density images at the mid-resolution range of 4-10Å. Such methods will be generally applicable to determine the structure of proteins for which no existing templates can be identified. Novel ideas will be implemented in two difficult but critical steps in this problem. The first one addresses the long-standing challenge of accurately identifying β-strands from density images. The second addresses the problem of finding the correct mapping of secondary structures (helices and β-strands) in a density map to those identified on the protein sequence in presence of errors, making use of advanced computational methods. This project is a multidisciplinary effort bringing together expertise from computational structural biology, data mining, efficient algorithm design, and parallel computing. The methodology to be developed will be validated using experimentally derived cryo-EM density images and will be incorporated into Chimera, a popular 3D molecular viewer, for the cryo-EM community.
The outcome of the project will be made available at the following website:   http://www.cs.odu.edu/~jhe/

por.por_cntn:
Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) has become a major structure determination technique for large molecular assemblies in which many molecules work together to provide biological functions. The significance of this technique is recognized by the 2017 Nobel Prize in chemistry that was given to three scientists with pioneering experimental and computational work in cryo-EM. Although many atomic structures have been determined to near-atomic resolutions from cryo-EM density maps (3-dimensional images) of high-resolutions (2-4 angstrom), significant number of biological specimen face heterogeneity problems that make it more difficult to obtain density maps of high-resolutions. In this project, we address key challenges in those density maps at medium resolutions (5-10 angstrom), at which certain level of details about the molecule is detectable but not sufficient for structure determination. The long-term goal of the project is to use advanced computational ideas to derive atomic structures from medium-resolution density maps.

Intellectual merits

  1. We addressed a long-standing open problem to derive orientations of β-strands when no traces of β-strands are visible in the density map. β-strands are about 4.5 angstrom apart. They are only resolvable in a high-resolution density map. They are not resolvable when the resolution is worse than 5 angstrom. Yet, the location of β-strands is critical for atomic structure determination. We developed a novel method, StrandTwister (Si et al. 2014), to derive orientation of β-strands through analysis of twist in local regions that are detected as β-sheets in the density map. We gave a further method, StrandRoller (Si et al. 2017) to derive orientations of β-strands in a β-barrel, a special type of β-sheet. In order to derive β-strands precisely, we proposed a method to measure the twist from continuous lines sampled from β-sheet regions of the density map (Islam et al. 2018).
  2. This project has brought together advanced computational techniques of deep learning and geometric modeling into the problem of secondary structure detection from cryo-EM density maps. We introduced the first two convolutional neural networks in this problem and results show great potential in this direction (Li et al. 2016, Haslam et al. 2018). In order to evaluate accuracy of protein secondary structure detection methods, we proposed an "arc-length association" method that sensitively detects small disagreement between central lines of secondary structures (Zeil et al. 2017).
  3. Due to the quality of density map at medium resolutions, secondary structure detection errors are inevitable and they need to be considered in modeling of atomic structures. Modeling with uncertainty is computationally expensive and effective algorithms are needed. We developed a dynamic programming algorithm to incorporate alternative positions of secondary structures in topology generation (Biswas et al. 2015, Biswas et al. 2016).
  4. We have developed a user interface for five of our methods (SSETracer, StrandTwister, AxisComparison, BundleTrac, Membrane Tracing) in analysis of density maps obtained from cryo-EM and cryo-electron tomography. The user interface is integrated in Chimera, a popular visualization and modeling software in the cryo-EM community (Haslam et al. 2018).

Broader Impact

This NSF-funded project has produced significant impact in both faculty development and student training at all levels. Although the main site of the project is at Old Dominion University (ODU), research and educational activities involve collaboration among nine faculty from five institutions, of which two are historically black universities. The project generated 24 peer-reviewed publications and provided research topics for four PhDs, of which two became assistant professors in US universities, one joined a national lab, and one joined industry. Eight PhD students, four master students, and 12 undergraduate students conducted individual projects mentored by the PI and Co-PIs. Seven undergraduate students have been motivated by research experiences in the NSF-funded project and decided to join graduate programs of ODU. One graduate student received 2nd prize in Tapia Student Poster Competition at ACM Richard TAPIA Celebration of Diversity in Computing Conference of 2017. Four undergraduate students received competitive research scholarships from Virginia Space Grant Consortium or ODU Honors College. Five undergraduate students are co-authors of eight peer-reviewed publications, three of which have undergraduate students as first authors. This project provided professional development opportunities for two junior faculty and one summer intern from historically black universities. Research components have been developed and incorporated in several undergraduate and graduate courses to challenge students with real world problems.

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2018
Modified by: Jing He
por.por_txt_cntn:
Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) has become a major structure determination technique for large molecular assemblies in which many molecules work together to provide biological functions. The significance of this technique is recognized by the 2017 Nobel Prize in chemistry that was given to three scientists with pioneering experimental and computational work in cryo-EM. Although many atomic structures have been determined to near-atomic resolutions from cryo-EM density maps (3-dimensional images) of high-resolutions (2-4 angstrom), significant number of biological specimen face heterogeneity problems that make it more difficult to obtain density maps of high-resolutions. In this project, we address key challenges in those density maps at medium resolutions (5-10 angstrom), at which certain level of details about the molecule is detectable but not sufficient for structure determination. The long-term goal of the project is to use advanced computational ideas to derive atomic structures from medium-resolution density maps.

Intellectual merits

We addressed a long-standing open problem to derive orientations of β-strands when no traces of β-strands are visible in the density map. β-strands are about 4.5 angstrom apart. They are only resolvable in a high-resolution density map. They are not resolvable when the resolution is worse than 5 angstrom. Yet, the location of β-strands is critical for atomic structure determination. We developed a novel method, StrandTwister (Si et al. 2014), to derive orientation of β-strands through analysis of twist in local regions that are detected as β-sheets in the density map. We gave a further method, StrandRoller (Si et al. 2017) to derive orientations of β-strands in a β-barrel, a special type of β-sheet. In order to derive β-strands precisely, we proposed a method to measure the twist from continuous lines sampled from β-sheet regions of the density map (Islam et al. 2018). 
This project has brought together advanced computational techniques of deep learning and geometric modeling into the problem of secondary structure detection from cryo-EM density maps. We introduced the first two convolutional neural networks in this problem and results show great potential in this direction (Li et al. 2016, Haslam et al. 2018). In order to evaluate accuracy of protein secondary structure detection methods, we proposed an "arc-length association" method that sensitively detects small disagreement between central lines of secondary structures (Zeil et al. 2017). 
Due to the quality of density map at medium resolutions, secondary structure detection errors are inevitable and they need to be considered in modeling of atomic structures. Modeling with uncertainty is computationally expensive and effective algorithms are needed. We developed a dynamic programming algorithm to incorporate alternative positions of secondary structures in topology generation (Biswas et al. 2015, Biswas et al. 2016). 
We have developed a user interface for five of our methods (SSETracer, StrandTwister, AxisComparison, BundleTrac, Membrane Tracing) in analysis of density maps obtained from cryo-EM and cryo-electron tomography. The user interface is integrated in Chimera, a popular visualization and modeling software in the cryo-EM community (Haslam et al. 2018).


Broader Impact

This NSF-funded project has produced significant impact in both faculty development and student training at all levels. Although the main site of the project is at Old Dominion University (ODU), research and educational activities involve collaboration among nine faculty from five institutions, of which two are historically black universities. The project generated 24 peer-reviewed publications and provided research topics for four PhDs, of which two became assistant professors in US universities, one joined a national lab, and one joined industry. Eight PhD students, four master students, and 12 undergraduate students conducted individual projects mentored by the PI and Co-PIs. Seven undergraduate students have been motivated by research experiences in the NSF-funded project and decided to join graduate programs of ODU. One graduate student received 2nd prize in Tapia Student Poster Competition at ACM Richard TAPIA Celebration of Diversity in Computing Conference of 2017. Four undergraduate students received competitive research scholarships from Virginia Space Grant Consortium or ODU Honors College. Five undergraduate students are co-authors of eight peer-reviewed publications, three of which have undergraduate students as first authors. This project provided professional development opportunities for two junior faculty and one summer intern from historically black universities. Research components have been developed and incorporated in several undergraduate and graduate courses to challenge students with real world problems.
